data.title: Research Guides at Mary Baldwin University
data.meta_description: Information regarding remaining race films, including full-length videos and quick links to more information.
data.text:
Borderline (1930) A black couple spend their vacation at a Swiss mountain resort with white guests.

The Darktown Revue (1931) Musical numbers and comedy routines from Donald Heywood's Choir and Tim Moore.

A Rhapsody In Black and Blue (1931) A man dreams that he is the king of Jazzmania after being hit on the head by a mop.

The Black King (1932) An unscrupulous minister starts a 'back to Africa' movement.

Harlem is Heaven (1932) Stage lovers are reunited by a dancer/director (Bill Robinson) in trouble with a racketeer.

Ten Minutes to Live (1932) A movie producer offers a nightclub singer a role in his latest film, but all he really wants to do is bed her. She knows, but accepts anyway. Meanwhile, a patron at the club gets a note saying that she will be killed.

Rufus Jones for President (1933) Rufus Jones, a black child, is elected President of the United States.

That's the Spirit (1933) Two night watchmen hear songs performed in a haunted pawn shop.

Bubbling Over (1934) A woman (Ethel Waters) works tirelessly to care for her lazy husband and relatives.

Drums o' Voodoo (1934) Saturday sinners and Sunday saints clash in the battle of good against evil.

Hi-De-Ho (1934) Cab Calloway advises a train conductor to get his wife a radio so she won't step out on him, but he is proved wrong after the conductor takes his advice.

King for a Day (1934) A talented tap dancer who can't get an audition uses his prowess at playing craps to gain ownership of a musical show, making himself the star.

An All-Colored Vaudeville Show (1935) Acrobats, racketeers, and musicians.

Jitterbug Party (1935) Cab Calloway performs two numbers at the Cotton Club, then takes his friends down to Harlem for a jitterbug party.

Murder in Harlem (1935) A black night watchman at a chemical factory finds the body of a murdered white woman. What he didn't expect was to be accused for her murder.

Sanders of the River (1935) Paul Robeson plays Bosambo, a self-appointed leader of the river people who respects "Sandi," the representative of the English crown in this part of West Africa. Complications arise when a bellicose tribal chief foments bloody rebellion by attacking Bosambo's people, and kidnapping his wife.

Symphony in Black (1935) Duke Ellington plays his symphonic jazz piece "A Rhapsody of Negro Life" with his orchestra against slice-of-life background scenes.

The Black Network (1936) The owner of a shoe polish company sponsors a radio show that showcases black performers. Since his wife's father put up the money to be the sponsor, she insists on singing on the show. Unfortunately for her, no level of prestige can make up for her lack of talent.

The Broken Earth (1936) A farmer (Clarence Muse) comes from the fields to find his young son dying. He prays to the Lord to save his only child.

A Study of Educational Inequalities in South Carolina (1936) A documentary produced by the National Association For the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) on the racial disparities in the education provided in South Carolina public schools.

Barbershop Blues (1937) Claude Hopkins Orchestra featuring Orlando Roberson and The Four Step Brothers

Big Fella (1937) A wanderer (Paul Robeson) and his friend (Elisabeth Welch) shelter a runaway who doesn't wish to return to his parents.

Dark Manhattan (1937) A Harlem gangster rises to power, but conflict ensues as his former associates move in for the kill.

Hi De Ho (1937) Young Cab Calloway's mother is concerned, because Cab spends his days listening to the radio, pretending to lead a miniature orchestra. A deacon passing by the apartment hears him singing and advises him go to his wife's gypsy tea room. As she reads the tea leaves, she sees situations which lead to Cab and his orchestra performing musical numbers.

Dark Sands (1937) Paul Robeson portrays Jericho, a falsely convicted soldier who flees from war time France to Africa.

Underworld (1937) A young man, graduate of a Southern black college, becomes a part of the Chicago underworld.

We Work Again (1937) A tribute to the Works Progress Administration (WPA) in their efforts to find jobs for African-Americans during the Great Depression of the 1930's.

The Duke Is Tops (1938) A successful performer who almost her man because his career as a producer is failing.

Gang Smashers (1938) Nina Mae McKinney plays an FBI agent who goes undercover to bring down a Harlem racketeer gangster.

God's Step Children (1938) A light-skinned child, abandoned by her mother, doesn't want to acknowledge her race.

The Spirit Of Youth (1938) A poor black fighter climbs to the top of the boxing world.

Swing! (1938) Ted Gregory wants to be the first black producer to mount a show on Broadway, but he has trouble with his star singer.

Two-Gun Man From Harlem (1938) A cowboy is wrongfully accused of murder, and winds up in Harlem where he assumes the identity of a preacher-turned-gangster. He uses his new identity to infiltrate the gang, and catch the men who framed him.

The Devil's Daughter (1939) After her father's death, a woman returns to Jamaica to run his banana plantation. Out of jealousy and spite, her stepsister attempts to banish her using voodoo.

Double Deal (1939) A gangster is double-crossed and ends up on the wrong end of a policeman's gun.

Harlem Rides the Range (1939) A cowboy and his sidekick try to help a homesteader from being cheated out of his property.

Keep Punching (1939) Despite the opposition raised by his father and his girlfriend, a golden gloves champion agrees to turn professional when approached by a fight manager.

Lying Lips (1939) A nightclub singer is convicted and sent to prison for the murder of her aunt, a detective set out to prove her innocence.

Moon Over Harlem (1939) A Harlem widow unwittingly marries a double-talking gangster.

Paradise In Harlem (1939) Comedian Lem Anderson's long-awaited dramatic act vanishes when he witnesses a mob killing and is forced to leave town.

Straight to Heaven (1939) Joe Williams is a chemist who recently lost his job to George Elliott. When George shows up dead, Joe is is the first suspect. The plot shifts when Joe's wife, Ida, infiltrates the gang that framed her husband and attempts to prove Joe's innocence.

Way Down South (1939) Based on the classic, critically acclaimed novel by Langston Hughes.

Broken Strings (1940) A black violinist injures his hands in an automobile accident, and his son and pupils work frivilously to raise money for his operation.

Gang War (1940) Two rival gangs struggle to control the jukebox machines in Harlem

Mystery In Swing (1940) In and around some great blues, a very unpopular band-leader, Prince Ellis, is killed in a Harlem nightclub. In an attempt to find the perpetrator, a detective finds the list of suspects is very long, as Prince Ellis was indeed very unpopular with many citizens.

The Proud Valley (AKA The Tunnel) (1940) Paul Robeson is called upon to make the ultimate sacrifice when a pit disaster threatens the town.

Son of Ingagi (1940) A newlywed couple is visited by a strange old woman who harbors a secret about the young girl's father.

Sunday Sinners (1940) A local preacher turns a blind eye to a nightclub so long as they stay closed on the Sabbath, but finds himself in hot water when the nightclub disobeys his wishes. Meanwhile the club owner has other problems on his plate, including a gang who wants to provide protection.

The Blood of Jesus (1941) A godly young woman in the rural south is accidentally shot by her husband. As she lies dying, an angel takes her soul on a symbolic journey, and the devil attempts to lure her with earthy temptations.

Lucky Ghost (1941) Two down-on-their luck friends suddenly hit the jackpot when they win the clothes, car and chauffeur of a rich man in a game of dice. They wind up in a sanitarium that's being used as an exclusive, though illegal, gambling club and get mixed up with beautiful women, jealous gangsters and ghosts.

Mistaken Identity (A.K.A. Murder With Music) (1941) A murder mystery which involves a woman who works at a nightclub, and her former boyfriend who escapes from prison.

Murder on Lenox Avenue (1941) Dramatic events unravel in a Harlem apartment house when Pa Wilkins is chosen by the Better Business League to replace their ousted, crooked leader Marshall.

Henry Browne, Farmer (1942) Documentary short film dramatizing the efforts of a black farmer and his family to help the American war effort by increasing production.

Negro Colleges In Wartime (1943) This 1940s educational film produced by the Office of War Information Bureau of Motion Pictures looks at how black universities across the country changed their curriculum during World War II.

The Negro Pilots (Tuskegee Pilots) (1943) At a dusty, booming airdrome in the Southeast Air Forces Training Center, the 99th Pursuit Squadron, world’s first Negro aerial fighting unit, is girding for its opening sky-joust with the enemy.

Strictly G.I. (1943) A filmed broadcast of the Command Performance radio programs in which various Hollywood stars appeared and performed in accordance with letter requests from American service men stationed around the world.

Where's My Man Tonight? (1943) Sergeant Robert L. Keen, an officer of the African-American 25th Regiment, is sent to many states on a recruitment tour.

Boogie-Woogie Dream (1944) After hours at a nightclub, the hired help have a jam session, which proves to be just what a couple of belated customers wanted to hear.

Go Down Death (1944) A bar owner attempts to discredit the new preacher with whom he is feuding by framing him with a photograph showing him drinking with scandalous women.

The Negro Soldier (1944) A film about life for black soldiers in the U.S. Army during World War II.

Of One Blood (1944) An FBI agent goes undercover and discovers a gang's leader is a childhood friend who saved his life when they were youth.

Big Timers (1945) A wealthy society man is dating a beautiful woman who he believes is also in his "socioeconomic class". In actuality, she is the daughter of a poor hotel maid.

The Negro Sailor (1945) A propaganda film, emphasizing the need for racial harmony for victory. The film was photographed by U.S. Navy camera crews and completed at Columbia Studios.

Open the Door, Richard (1945) A musically themed film cutting back and forth between Stepin Fetchit at home in bed, and a jazz band that provides the film's swing music.

Beale Street Mama (1946) A street cleaner and his pal, find some stolen money which they use to try to establish themselves in the good life. They are found out and end up losing everything.

Beware (1946) A former student comes to the rescue of his alma mater (a Black College) by exposing the unscrupulous tactics of the college president.

Dirty Gertie (1946) Gertie is on the run from the man she has jilted.

The Girl In Room 20 (1946) A girl from a small town in Texas, moves to New York City to pursue her dream of becoming a singer. However, her dreams prove to be far more difficult to realize than she had ever imagined.

Midnight Menace (1946) A strange voodoo man can kill women and then move their bodies wherever he wants. This time, he just wants to torment Lollypop Jones with a body that keeps showing up no matter where he goes.

Tall, Tan, and Terrific (1946) A nightclub owner and his gambling problem lands him in trouble for a crime he didn't commit.

Boy! What A Girl! (1947) An ex-prizefighter dresses up like a woman to woo a Chicago businessman into investing in a business.

Hi-De-Ho (1947) Cab Calloway is pressured into leaving the Brass Nightclub in favor of a criminally run night club across the street.

Juke Joint (1947) Two broke con men get involved in a small town beauty pageant.

Junction 88 (1947) Small town lovers are aided by a visiting showman.

Lookout Sister (1947) A cowboy helps a pretty ranch owner save her ranch from the scheming mortgage holder who wants to foreclose so he can claim the oil he has discovered on the property.

Reet, Petite, and Gone (1947) A crooked lawyer plans to scheme a wealthy, retired musical star, but the son must stop the lawyer.

Sepia Cinderella (1947) A songwriter and a singer who, after trials and tribulations, get back together to the tune of his "Cinderella Song."

Woman's A Fool (1947) A refreshing perspective on burlesque queens, exotic dancers, comedians, and song and dance routines galore.

Boarding House Blues (1948) An evil landlord intends to evict "Moms Mabley" and her tenants from her boarding house because she can't pay the rent.

Miracle In Harlem (1948) A crooked real estate tycoon tricks a trusting young woman out of her small candy store. When he is found dead, the girl is suspected of the crime.

No Time for Romance (1948) An unconfident composer is discovered by a singing star. They both make each other's dreams come true while overcoming a jealous has-been plan to ruin them.

The Quiet One (1948) The story of a young boy growing up in Harlem.

Mr. Adam's Bomb (1949) A police detective and his silly sidekick investigate a family's concern that an uncle may be experimenting with explosives.

Souls of Sin (1949) Tired of being broke, an unsuccessful gambler engages in illegal activities.
